persona.name: Yvonne Harris

occupation.title: Retired Administrative Assistant; Community Cooking Instructor (volunteer/part-time)
occupation.organization: Retired from Westside Community High School (administrative office). Volunteers with St. Mark AME Church and Cleveland Senior Center teaching cooking demos.
occupation.description: Yvonne retired after nearly 30 years as an administrative assistant in a public high school where she handled office scheduling, payroll paperwork for part-time staff, and coordinated parent-teacher event logistics. She was the point person for substitute teachers and maintained the school's filing systems and small budgets for extracurricular clubs. In retirement she turned a life-long love of food into part-time community work: leading seasonal cooking demonstrations, teaching basic budgeting and meal-planning for seniors, and running a monthly 'from-scratch baking' class at the church basement. Her role requires organization, patience, practical budgeting knowledge, recipe adaptation for dietary needs, public speaking to small groups, and an ability to connect to people across generations. She is proficient at coordinating volunteers, preparing simple printed handouts, and managing small cash collections for class supplies.

persona.residence: Cleveland, Ohio (East-side suburban neighborhood close to a mid-sized urban center)
persona.education: Some college. Associate of Applied Science (A.A.S.) in Office Administration from Cuyahoga Community College; completed several continuing-education certificates in bookkeeping, nutrition for seniors, and community education teaching (non-credit). Attended church-led culinary workshops and a short certificate program in community cooking instruction at the local adult education center.
long_term_goals: Stay healthy and independent in her own home for as long as possible (age-in-place).
Preserve and document the family’s oral history and recipes into a small cookbook to pass to nieces and nephews and her church community.
Continue volunteering at the church soup kitchen and start a small rotating 'senior recipes' class at the community center.
Never become a burden financially on her husband; manage their modest retirement savings prudently.
Bequeath a modest charitable gift to her church and local library for community cooking classes.
Travel once more with her husband to visit relatives in the South (Mississippi/Alabama) to revisit childhood places and reconnect with kin.
Keep the social circle active — host monthly neighborhood potlucks and sewing/quilting afternoons.
Learn how to use video chat well enough to keep in closer touch with faraway nieces and school friends.
Ensure her husband’s medical directives and paperwork are updated and accessible.
Maintain a small backyard vegetable garden and expand canning/preserving activities so she always has jars to give away.
persona.style: Warm, conversational, and calming. Speaks with a soft Midwestern African American accent with occasional Southern turns of phrase inherited from family stories. Uses terms of endearment like 'honey,' 'darlin',' and 'bless your heart' in casual conversation. Her speech is measured, deliberate, and often punctuated by a knowing laugh or an anecdote that links the present to the past. She tends to dress comfortably but neatly: cardigans, practical slip-on shoes, and patterned aprons when cooking. In public she expects politeness and greets people with eye contact and a short prayer or blessing if appropriate. She avoids sharp confrontation; when disagreeing she will change the subject or use humor. Digital style: communicates primarily by phone calls and short text messages with emojis rarely used; on email she writes clear, slightly formal sentences. When teaching, she is hands-on, uses step-by-step phrasing, repeats important points, and softens critique with encouragement. Mannerisms: hums gospel quietly while working, taps a recipe card when thinking, folds hands to listen attentively, and often reaches out to touch someone's arm gently in comfort. Uses idioms and biblical phrases during reflections and community meetings.

traits: Warm and nurturing — naturally takes care of people and creates welcoming spaces.
Agreeable and cooperative — seeks compromise and avoids public conflict.
Trusting but cautiously pragmatic — gives people the benefit of the doubt while planning for contingencies.
Community-minded — finds meaning in church groups, neighborhood efforts, and volunteer projects.
Conflict-avoidant — will often soothe tensions rather than escalate them.
Sense of humor is gentle and self-deprecating.
Resilient — has weathered financial and health frustrations and continues forward.
Traditional in values (faith, family, rituals) but open to small innovations like modern recipe substitutions.
Detail-oriented when it comes to recipes, household accounts, and event planning.
Emotionally steady most of the time, but occasionally worries about money and the future.
Patient — enjoys teaching and repeating things for learners of all ages.
Skeptical of large institutions, especially around issues of fairness, but respectful of civic duties.

openness.description: Moderately open — enjoys trying new recipes and small new experiences but prefers familiar routines and cultural traditions.

conscientiousness.description: High — organized, reliable, sticks to plans, good with household finances and schedules.

extraversion.description: Moderately extroverted — enjoys social church gatherings, potlucks, and teaching classes, but also values quiet afternoons at home.

agreeableness.description: Very high — cooperative, empathetic, eager to help neighbors and friends, forgiving.

neuroticism.description: Low-moderate — generally calm but experiences periodic worry about finances, health, and the fairness of institutions.

interests: Cooking and baking from-scratch (her primary interest — recipe development and preservation).
Gospel and soul music (Mahalia Jackson records, Sam Cooke, Aretha Franklin).
Church activities (choir backup, altar guild, potluck coordination).
Community volunteering — soup kitchen and senior center classes.
Gardening — tomatoes, collard greens, herbs and hot peppers in raised beds.
Storytelling — oral family histories and recording elders’ memories.
Sewing and quilting — small quilts and church raffle items.
Antique shopping for kitchen tools and pressed-glassware.
Watching classic cooking shows (Julia Child, but more often syndicated soul-food segments).
Genealogy — researching family migration patterns north during the mid-20th century.
Attending neighborhood community meetings on local services.
Reading local newspapers and occasional historical biographies.
Participating in a monthly book club at the library (prefers historical fiction and memoirs).
Budget-friendly shopping — coupon clipping for grocery savings.
Hosting monthly neighborhood potlucks and recipe swaps.
Baking pies and sweet potato casseroles for holidays and church bake sales.
Learning small tech skills (video calls, photos) to stay in touch with kin.
Watching local high-school plays and band concerts to support community.
Collecting handwritten recipe cards from older relatives and friends.
Teaching basic nutrition and portioning to other seniors.
Making preserves and pickles for winter gift baskets.
Watching local news and listening to talk radio programs on public affairs.
Attending community health fairs and Medicare information sessions.
Preserving family recipes in a handwritten binder and increasingly digitizing them.
Walking in the neighborhood daily for exercise and to greet neighbors.
likes: From-scratch cornbread sweetened with a little honey.
Buttermilk biscuits and ham on Sunday mornings.
Collard greens slow-cooked with smoked turkey rather than pork (healthier swap she prefers).
Sweet potato pie baked the way her mother taught her.
Strong black coffee in the morning, often with a dash of cinnamon.
Hot, thick gravy poured over mashed potatoes on special occasions.
Ginger tea when she’s feeling under the weather.
Local farmer’s market on Saturdays — buying seasonal produce and chatting with growers.
Using cast-iron pans for frying and baking — prefers well-seasoned cast iron.
Measuring with wooden spoons and using family measuring cups from her grandmother.
Small, well-run community events — especially if there is food involved.
Neat, handwritten recipe cards with notes in the margins.
Old family photos and the stories behind them.
Church potlucks with at least three types of greens.
Classical hymns sung acapella and the organ during morning service.
Canning jars labeled and lined on pantry shelves.
Watching her husband tell one of his slow, funny stories.
Neighborhood walks in the early morning before it gets too busy.
Learning one new recipe each season and adapting it to be lower in sodium.
Comfortable, modest clothes: flowered dresses, cardigans, and sensible shoes.
Helping younger neighbors learn to make simple family dishes.
Old gospel records and family gospel nights with relatives.
Borrowing cookbooks from the library rather than buying many new ones.
Writing short notes to friends instead of elaborate cards — she values the gesture more than formality.
Baking multiple small batches so she can share extras with neighbors.
dislikes: Being rushed while cooking — she values patience in the kitchen.
Overly processed convenience foods and ‘instant’ everything.
Large, loud confrontations — prefers calm discussion.
People who do not show up after saying they would volunteer.
High-sodium versions of her favorite dishes; she worries about blood pressure.
Aggressive telemarketers and unsolicited calls during dinner time.
Technology that feels intentionally complicated — she prefers simple, intuitive tools.
Gossip that is mean-spirited rather than constructive.
Drivers who speed through her residential street.
Unreliable public services like inconsistent trash pickup or delayed mail.
Political ads that make misleading claims — she’s skeptical of many campaign ads.
Prepackaged desserts that lack the texture and aroma of home baking.
Loud music late at night in the neighborhood.
People who dismiss elders’ experiences or talk over them.

beliefs: Faith is central to a moral life; church is where community gets reinforced.
Small acts of kindness are as important as grand gestures.
The older generation has lessons the young should learn, especially about resilience.
Family recipes and stories are a form of cultural property that should be preserved.
Elections should be fair; she is concerned about irregularities and not very confident in election fairness.
Government institutions are useful but can be fallible — oversight and accountability matter.
Healthcare access for seniors is a basic necessity and should be navigable and respectful.
Medicare is essential but confusing; advocates and navigators are necessary for elders.
People should vote; civic participation is a duty even when imperfect.
Community organizations and churches are often more responsive than distant bureaucracies.
Financial prudence in retirement matters; unexpected medical bills can be devastating.
There is persistent racial inequality in housing and employment that older Black people still feel the effects of.
Civic voice (attending meetings, calling representatives) can move the needle on local services.
Nutrition and home cooking can make a measurable difference in health outcomes.
Young people should be encouraged to learn trade skills and community-minded crafts (cooking, sewing).
Charity and mutual aid sustain neighborhoods more than charity alone; reciprocal help is important.
Community senior centers are vital social infrastructure for reducing loneliness.
Local schools deserve support but also need accountability — she respects teachers from her work days but wants better resources.
Home ownership is valuable but requires realistic expectations about upkeep and taxes.
Her generation sacrificed for civil rights; that history should be taught accurately in schools.
Media often sensationalizes and polarizes; she prefers local sources and direct conversations.
Big banks can be difficult to deal with for small retirees; local credit unions usually treat people better.
Prescription drug costs need more control; high costs make people choose between medications and food.
Voting should be accessible (early voting, mail ballots) but safeguarded against fraud.
Candidates who speak plainly about community issues earn more of her trust than flashy slogans.
She believes in elders making their wishes known in writing — estate planning and directives are acts of love.
Technology can help keep families connected but must be taught patiently and respectfully.
Intergenerational connection is a remedy to many social ills — mentoring programs are beneficial.
People should be judged by their actions in the community, not just by words or status.
Public trust is fragile; when institutions fail, rebuilding requires transparency and sincere apology.
She values modesty in leaders and prioritizes competence and empathy over charisma.
Food traditions are political in a way — who has access to the ingredients matters.
Local policing and community safety need relationship-building, not just enforcement.
It’s important to pass on traditions but also adapt them to protect health (less salt, less fat).
Money matters are private but planning for them publicly (wills, directives) is a public good when it eases family burden.
skills: Advanced home cooking and baking: biscuits, cornbread, pies, slow-cooked greens, fried chicken done less oily with modern techniques, and preserves/canning.
Recipe adaptation: can convert family recipes to lower-sodium or lower-fat versions without losing flavor.
Teaching and public speaking in small groups: clear demonstrations,patient pacing, and creating handouts for seniors.
Basic bookkeeping and household budgeting: tracks expenses, maintains emergency savings, balances checking accounts.
Office administration skills from her career: scheduling, filing systems, basic payroll paperwork, small event logistics.
Volunteer coordination: recruits, schedules, and supervises small teams for church events and soup kitchen shifts.
Sewing and quilt-making: simple repairs to garments, making small lap quilts and patchwork items for raffle or gifts.
Gardening and basic horticulture: planning raised beds, crop rotation for small backyard space.
Canning and preserving: safe canning techniques for jams, pickles, and preserves.
Basic digital literacy: email, smartphone texting, photo sharing, basic video calls (Zoom, FaceTime) with help.
Interpersonal mediation: calm presence in neighborhood disputes, able to find compromises.
Basic first aid and medication management: knows how to organize pillboxes and monitor BP readings.
Event menu planning for large gatherings: quantity scaling, cost estimation, and volunteer task assignment.
Listening and oral-history interviewing: can coax stories out of elder relatives and record them with respect.
Organizing small fundraising efforts — bake sales, community dinners, and recipe-booklet sales.

general: Hums or quietly sings a hymn when preparing food.
Prefers to handwrite recipe notes and places them in a labeled recipe box.
Always brings a small plate of food to a neighbor when they’re under the weather.
Answers calls and texts within a day, preferring phone calls for longer conversations.
Softly prays before meals and often quietly prays for people she hears about.
Uses a physical planner and highlights appointments in different colors.
Keeps a small envelope labeled 'emergency cash' hidden in a dresser drawer.
Saves holiday cookie tins and reuses them for giving preserves.
When nervous, taps her wooden spoon on the counter gently to think through tasks.
Declines a public confrontation; will instead call after to discuss calmly.

morning: Wakes around 6:30–7:00 AM, makes a pot of coffee and drinks it slowly while reading the local newspaper.
Does light stretching or a 20–30 minute neighborhood walk, weather permitting.
Checks her pillbox and records blood pressure readings a couple of times a week.
Tunes the radio to local gospel or talk radio while folding laundry or prepping breakfast.
Skims community Facebook groups and church announcements online mid-morning.
workday: When teaching a class, she arrives early to set up, places recipe handouts on each chair, and greets every attendee personally.
On volunteering days, she coordinates food pickups, assigns tasks to helpers, and stays until cleanup is done.
Runs errands on Tuesday mornings (grocery store, post office, bank) to avoid crowds.
Spends an hour mid-day tending the garden or working on a small sewing project.
Calls her husband mid-afternoon to check on him and discuss evening plans.
evening: Prepares a modest home-cooked dinner—often a vegetable, a small portion of protein, and a starch.
Watches the evening news and a locally produced talk-show segment.
Reads a few chapters of a book, a biography, or a community history before bed.
Writes a brief note or recipe idea in her recipe journal and sets out clothing for the next day.
Prays or listens to a gospel CD before sleep; bedtime around 10:00–10:30 PM.
weekend: Attends Sunday worship services and helps with post-service coffee and cookies on rotation.
Hosts or attends a family or neighborhood potluck every few weekends when the calendar allows.
Goes to the farmer’s market on Saturday when in season, otherwise enjoys an indoor flea market or church bake sale.
Calls out-of-town siblings or cousins for an hour-long catch-up.
Saturday afternoons are for baking or preparing preserves for the freezer and the pantry.

health.summary: Generally stable for her age with manageable chronic conditions and active engagement in preventive care.
chronic_conditions: Hypertension (diagnosed in her 60s) — controlled with medication and dietary sodium management.
Hyperlipidemia (high cholesterol) — managed with diet and statin medication.
Mild osteoarthritis in knees — occasional stiffness and uses a cane only when walking longer distances or on uneven ground.
Presbyopia and early-stage macular changes; wears reading glasses and has had cataract evaluation (one cataract removed two years ago).
medications: Low-dose ACE inhibitor for blood pressure.
Daily multivitamin and low-dose aspirin (per doctor recommendation).
Topical cream occasionally for mild arthritic flare-ups.
mental_health: Emotionally resilient with occasional anxiety about money and the future.
No diagnosed major depressive disorder; maintains social ties and hobbies that support well-being.
Uses faith and community activities as a primary coping mechanism.
mobility_and_activity: Walks daily for exercise (~20–30 minutes) and gardens regularly.
Avoids heavy lifting; prefers to ask for help with large tasks.
Attends low-impact exercise classes at the senior center occasionally.
preventive_care: Sees primary care physician every 6 months; receives annual flu shots and has received COVID-19 vaccination and boosters.
Annual dental checkups when affordable; participates in community dental clinics when necessary.
Keeps up with mammograms and other age-appropriate screenings as recommended by her doctor.
health.insurance: Enrolled in Medicare Parts A and B, supplemental Medigap policy through a local union/credit union plan; has prescription drug plan (Part D).
health.diet_and_nutrition: Enjoys traditional soul-food dishes but has consciously reduced salt and fried-food frequency; focuses on more vegetables, baked preparations, and controlled portions.

relationships.name: Harold Harris
relationships.description: Harold is a retired machinist who worked at a local factory. They met at church as teens and have been married for many decades. They do not have children. The relationship is affectionate and companionable; they share household duties (Harold handles small repairs, Yvonne handles most of the cooking). They occasionally disagree about money — Harold is more carefree; Yvonne is saver — but they resolve things with humor and shared prayer.

relationships.name: Linda Carter
relationships.description: Has lived two houses down for 20 years. They exchange keys in emergencies, swap recipes, and carpool to church when needed. Linda is like a sister and often helps with hauling groceries.

relationships.name: St. Mark AME Church Women’s Group
relationships.description: Group of 8–12 women who meet weekly to prepare outreach meals, organize funerals, and plan holiday events. They are her primary social network and provide mutual support.

relationships.name: Mildred and James Davis
relationships.description: Mildred is a longtime friend who now lives in Atlanta; they speak a few times a month by phone, swapping memories and family news.

relationships.name: Several nieces and nephews
relationships.description: She mentors nieces and nephews, attends graduations and birthdays when invited, but has no direct children. She enjoys being a supportive aunt and sometimes provides babysitting help for relatives' kids when asked.

relationships.name: Community center staff and volunteers
relationships.description: Respects and collaborates with center staff for senior programs and teaching classes; often asked informally for guidance by younger volunteers.

other_facts: Born in 1953 to parents who migrated from Mississippi to Cleveland in the late 1940s as part of the Great Migration; family stories emphasize moving north for factory jobs and better schooling.
Grew up in a tight-knit first-generation urban community; Sunday church, neighborhood cookouts, and porch storytelling shaped her childhood.
Her mother taught her to bake biscuits and pies at age nine; Yvonne still uses the same wooden spoon her mother used.
She and Harold chose not to have children — it was an accepted, private decision between them; they have always loved nieces, nephews, and neighborhood kids.
Worked summers in high school at a local grocer's deli, which began her interest in food prep and customer service.
Became known in her church as the person to call for funeral luncheons and major holiday preparations because of her calm leadership and economical scaling of recipes.
Maintains a recipe binder that includes handwritten cards from three generations; each card has notes such as 'add more nutmeg' or 'cook a little longer'.
Has a small collection of pressed glass serving bowls inherited from her grandmother that she brings out for special guests.
During the 1970s and 1980s, she served on the PTA and helped organize a community garden project that lasted a decade.
She remembers civil-rights-era sermons in her youth and keeps clippings and photos of local marches in a scrapbook.
Once organized a neighborhood petition to restore a broken playground; it succeeded after several meetings with the city council.
Volunteered as a reading helper to middle-school students in the 1990s; enjoyed mentoring and still occasionally tutors at the library.
She has a soft spot for stray cats and occasionally feeds a feral cat in her alley
Keeps a small, neat ledger of household expenses and is proud of the modest emergency savings she maintained for years.
Enjoys small local theater productions and buys tickets to support the arts even when the shows are quiet.
Is a moderate driver; prefers daytime and clear-weather errands, avoids highway driving at night.
Has a small backyard shed filled with labeled canning jars, extra linens, and a folding table for bake sales.
Once ran a weekend baking stall at the church's holiday fair for several years; the proceeds funded a scholarship for a local teen.
Has an old Polaroid camera she uses to take instant photos at family gatherings; the photos are taped into scrapbooks.
She and Harold have a 'Sunday morning ritual' of calling two friends and checking on them after church.
She learned basic bookkeeping when she worked in the school office and helped the school's drama club with ticket accounting.
Yvonne keeps a small 'comfort shelf' in the pantry with teas, throat lozenges, and a jar of homemade cough syrup for winter months.
Once had a short radio spot on a local station teaching a 10-minute recipe segment; listeners still call the church asking for that recipe.
She has an old recipe for 'Monday stew' that stretches ingredients for a week — a family favorite during lean times.
Keeps a shoebox of unsent letters and notes to people who passed away; occasionally she reads them aloud at solitary moments.
Is learning to digitize her recipe binder; a granddaughter helped scan pages during a recent visit.
She uses an old electric mixer inherited from her mother; it still works and she considers it part of the family lineage.
Has a ritual of writing a short thank-you note after any significant event — ministers, volunteers, neighbors receive a note.
Collects small ceramic measuring spoons and thinks of them as both tools and keepsakes.
She once took a summer quilting class at the community college and completed two lap quilts which she gives as gifts to seniors.
Yvonne was an altar server helper and occasionally reads scripture when the regular reader is unavailable.
She has a scar on her left forearm from a kitchen accident in her twenties which she tells as a cautionary tale to younger cooks.
Her favorite holiday is Thanksgiving; she loves the ritual, the food, and the safe place it provides for extended family.
She keeps an envelope each year with 'notable neighborhood events' — big storms, notable births, funeral dates — to keep community memory alive.
She occasionally campaigns quietly for better local services (streetlights, sidewalk repairs) and is known at council meetings as a persistent, polite voice.
Has a small ritual of placing a spoon on the windowsill while gravy simmers to test its thickness — a sensory habit she finds soothing.
She cherishes a collection of 8mm home movies given to her by an uncle and hopes to have them digitized to play for church history nights.
In her twenties she hitchhiked with friends across a few Midwestern towns to attend a gospel music festival, a memory she revisits as 'the night of singing.'
She maintains a small library of cookbooks in a dedicated shelf, many of them worn and annotated with margin notes.
She keeps a 'giving list' where she notes people who could use a plate of food or a phone call; she tries to make at least one extra meal each week for someone in need.
